title: Joe Hockey savages Donald Trump’s 'America First' trade mercantilism
text:
“It doesn’t make sense," the ambassador said.

Mr Trump has repeatedly justified his trade war against China, and threats against other economies including Europe, Canada, Mexico and even Australia, on the basis that such conflicts are “easy to win”.

Mr Hockey argued in his speech, which began with a historical tour of America's role in the creation at Bretton Woods in 1944 of the post-war global economic order, that such arguments fail to recognise the benefits of specialisation within economies.

“I want my doctor to be the best doctor they can be,” he said. “I don’t expect them to be able to build my house. The same is true for international trade”.

Mr Hockey’s remarks, to Westminster College in Fulton, Missouri on Thursday (Friday AEST), come almost a month to the day after Prime Minister Scott Morrison basked in the glow of a White House state dinner in the Rose Garden.

That meeting was largely ignored by US media, but in the weeks since there have been mutterings around some quarters in Washington that Australia’s government has made itself conspicuous by yoking itself too closely to a flawed president, who now faces only the third impeachment trial in American history.

In his speech, Mr Hockey hammered against the argument that trade deficits are a bad thing - which is one of Mr Trump’s primary economic justifications for slapping tariffs on China.

“Australia, like the United States, is a rich nation because whatever it doesn’t consume, it then sells around the world. And both nations are blessed with plenty.

“The sensible middle ground of society understands that when we trade freely with other nations, our nation gets richer.”

“Protectionism discourages growth and rewards mediocrity,” Mr Hockey said.

In an attack on the Trump administration’s attempts to undermine the World Trade Organisation and other multilateral groups, Mr Hockey said that while the US is the “most innovative nation on earth” like any market leader “it will be beaten if it thinks it can do it all on its own.”

“Sooner or later the remaining 95 per cent of the world population that lives outside the United States will catch up!”

He added that the use of tariffs to attack China is not a “sustainable long-term solution", saying tariffs are “imposed by governments on their own people” - challenging another talking point of Mr Trump that China is "paying" for the imposts.

“If citizens of other countries don’t have the same restrictions, they win," Mr Hockey said.

“In the 21st century, the consumer demands sovereignty. And consumer sovereignty is powered by the free flow of goods and services around the world. The end game must always be a free and fair global trading system.”

Mr Hockey is due to finish his term as ambassador in January.
description: Ambassador Joe Hockey’s stunningly blunt message to Donald Trump on protectionism and world trade: “If you abdicate leadership you rarely get it back”
